document_data.mainbody: [[T'u Lung]] was an oppressive and politically unstable country in [[Kara-Tur]]. After splitting from [[Shou Lung]] after a rebellion, the two states were at war for almost 250 years.
document_data.Geography:
T'u Lung was split into six provinces: [[Joi Chang Peninsula]], [[Ausa (province)|Ausa]], [[Bashan Do]], and [[Fengnao Province]]. Each province was administered by a hereditary governor and divided into several districts.

A vast range of climates and environments could be found within T'u Lung, including mountains, hills, rivers, lakes and plains.<ref name==KT:TM">

Politics.Government:
T'u Lung was split into six [[wikipedia:province|provinces]], each ruled by a hereditary [[wikipedia:governor|governor]]. The Emperor of T'u Lung was the overall leader but his power was diminished by the numerous wealthy noble families that controlled the various offices across the country. In order to gain support for his rebellion against the north, Emperor Shin Gisen had given power to the wealthy noble families. However, after T'u Lung was established as its own nation, it became near-impossible for the Emperor to regain this power. Several centuries later, the noble families still held a lot of power to the extent that the Emperor couldn't enforce his edicts without consent from the majority of nobles.

The administration of T'u Lung was largely corrupt and favored only the wealthy. Commoners had almost no chance of rising up into positions of government.
Politics.Foreign Relations:
Although major incursions from Shou Lung ended in {{YearlinkConvert|2258|SY}}, small skirmishes continued to occur and relations with Shou Lung remained fragile.

T'u Lung had diplomatic relations with [[Tabot]], [[Wa]], and [[Kozakura]]. These were set up in {{YearlinkConvert|2589|SY}}  as a response to Shou Lung beginning the "[[Gathering of Pearls]]".

Along the coast of the jungles south of T'u Lung, there were several small city-states that formed alliances with T'u Lung and paid regular tributes.

document_data.Economy:
The most common trade in T'u Lung was farming, which occurred almost everywhere in the country but especially along the banks of the Fenghsintzu river. In the southern hills of T'u Lung, lumbering was more widespread.

Taxation in T'u Lung was strict but many managed to avoid paying each year. Everyone who made money in T'u Lung (including adventurers) was required to pay exactly one third of their income to township officers. Tax evasion could lead to confiscation of all assets and deportation.

T'u Lung minted its own [[Currency|coinage]], although the currency used the same values and denominations as the Shou Lung currency. The exchange rate with Shou Lung coins was notoriously bad as away from the border Shou Lung currency had basically no value.

Demographics.Ethnic Groups:
Kara-Tur wasn't home to any indigenous populations of [[elves]], [[dwarves]] or other humanoids common in [[Faerûn]].

The majority of humans of T'u Lung shared racial characteristics like [[wikipedia:epicanthic fold|epicanthic folds]], brown eyes, and fine, straight black hair.<ref> T'u Lung people were also known to be slightly taller with thinner cheekbones than the humans in neighboring lands.<ref>
Demographics.Language: The most common language spoken in T'u Lung was [[Kao te Shou]], as in Shou Lung. Local accents and dialects of Kao te Shou were numerous and varied greatly across the country.In ''[[Kara-Tur: The Eastern Realms]]'', it states that T'u Lung uses the same language as Shou Lung, which is Kao te Shou, but the "Speaking in Tongues" article in the [[Dragon Magazine Annual 1999|1999 ''Dragon Magazine Annual'']] states that "T'u Lung" is also a language of its own. This could be explained in a number of ways; perhaps the people of T'u Lung renamed the language after their rebellion or perhaps "T'u Lung" is a particular distinct dialect of Kao te Shou known only by a minority of inhabitants.

Culture.Events & Festivals: Once a year, on the fifth day of the month of [[Kara-Tur calendar|Yu]], the inhabitants of T'u Lung celebrated the [[Festival to Welcome the Ethers]].
Culture.Cuisine: [[wikipedia:rice|Rice]] was by far the most common food in T'u Lung. It was served in some form with every meal. In both Shou Lung and T'u Lung, the most commonly used greeting was "''Have you eaten rice today?''". This had the same effect as saying "''Hello''" in Faerûn and showed how important rice was in daily life. Fish was the most commonly consumed meat and tea the most popular drink.

document_data.History:
After the Emperor of Shou Lung died before naming an heir, civil war broke out between the north and the south. The northern factions backed [[Shin Lu]], while the southern lords of T'u Lung backed [[Shin Gisen]].In Kara-tur, the years are marked using the [[Marking_the_Years#Shou_Calender|Shou Calender]], which are counted from the year [[Nung Fu]] first ascended the throne as Emperor. This article will refer to dates using the Shou Lung calender with the [[Marking_the_Years#Dalereckoning_.28DR.29|Dalereckoning]] year in parentheses. Shin Gisen was made Emperor of T'u Lung and the nation was officially founded.

In [[1116 DR|2366 (1116 DR)]], Emperor [[Shin Rokan]] tried to remove power from the barons and increase taxes. He was soon assassinated by [[Wai Long Hwa]], who proclaimed himself Emperor. Some of the powerful noble families made alliances and seceded from the Emperor and the period of the "Three Kingdoms" began.

In [[1169 DR|2419 (1169 DR)]], a potter of [[Chedoru]] named [[Jo He Ting]] created a set of eight magical bowls for the imperial court. Anyone who ate from the bowls was bestowed with clear thought for an hour after using them. Four years later, in [[1173 DR|2424 (1173 DR)]], Emperor [[Wai Chu Doang]] was killed by poison while using the bowls.

After the death of [[Wai Lo Yan]], one of T'u Lung's most long-lived emperors, the only heir was his daughter [[Wai Yeh Ying]]. Tradition meant that she should have been made emperor but the nobles of T'u Lung instead made her regent until Wai Lo Yan's nephew came of age.

After 242 years of conflicts and incursions with Shou Lung, diplomatic overtures were made and major invasions ceased. Despite this, Shou Lung continued to send small forces into T'u Lung on a regular basis, justifying these intrusions as hunting fleeing criminals.

[[Wai Yong]], the young tenth emperor of the [[Lui Dynasty]], secretly visited the western nation of [[Mulhorand]] under an assumed identity in [[1375 DR|2625 (1375 DR)]]. The reasons for this journey were unknown.
document_data.Notable Settlements:
;[[Ausa (city)|Ausa]]
:Ausa was a large city and port in the Ausa province. The port was known for its fifteen wharves, each one named after a different god. There was a natural spring in the center of the city, which provided water for the entire population. Just off the east coast of the port was the [[Xifung Reef]]. This reef caused a lot of trouble for navigators and was said to be haunted.
;[[Balanzia]]
:Once one of the largest and most powerful port cities in Kara-Tur, Balanzia was destroyed in [[1153 DR|2403 (1153 DR)]]. After surviving numerous attacks from Shou Lung forces, the city's walls were brought down by a powerful [[elemental]] and the inhabitants of Balanzia were driven mad with fear. Within a month, the city was desolate and haunted. People avoided the city for many decades to come.
;[[Ca'hong Chwi]]
:Also known as the "Flooded City", Ca'hong Chwi used to be a mighty fortress. When the south rebelled against the north in 2316 (1066 DR), the walled town of Ca'hong Chwi remained loyal to Shou Lung and was laid siege by the armies of T'u Lung. T'u Lung forces couldn't bring down the walls of Ca'hong Chwi and were ready to abandon the siege when [[Wantu Fang]] invented a strategy. The T'u Lung forces headed north away from the fortress and built the [[S'tuni Dam]]. After four months, the fortress of Ca'hong Chwi began to flood. Centuries later, all that could be seen of Ca'hong Chwi was the tops of five towers rising out of [[Sin Bukai]] lake. The towers were rumored to be haunted.
;[[Ha'chou]]
:Ha'chou was a well-kept city with strict law enforcement. The city had 25 towers and each one was painted a different color. One of Ha-chou's most famous residents was the sage [[Nift|Nift of the Silver Eye]]. He was the keeper of a vast library and only ever allowed one person entry to his archives at any one time.
;[[Wai]] (formerly "Chia Wan Ch'uan")
:Wai was the capital of T'u Lung and also the home of the Emperor. The oldest part of the city was founded in [[-781 DR|469 (−781 DR)]]. The city was filled with all kinds of life; from squalor to the most extravagant palaces in the entire country. The majority of the city was well kept and splendid. The city was also rife with political plotting and scheming. Often innocent bystanders would be dragged into political conflicts or arrested by paranoid officials for being in the wrong place at the wrong time.
document_data.Notable Locations:
;E'do Formal Gardens
:The formal gardens of E'do were considered to be the ultimate tranquility in all of T'u Lung. The gardens were vast and contained many separate groves and sections. The innermost grove never needed tending and was rarely visited, thanks to the shrine at its center that bestowed [[Arcane magic|arcane]] visions—often sending people mad. Numerous historic events took place in the [[E'do Formal Gardens]] over the years.
;The Fenghsintzu River
:Used as the main method of travel in T'u Lung, the [[Fenghsintzu River]] had many names. The river was home to a variety of wildlife, including [[crocodile]]s and [[water buffalo]] as well as water serpents that were able to sink 40-ft-long barges.
;I'wa Geyser
:The [[I'wa Geyser]] was a natural spring that shot boiling sulfur every three hours. The site also held three shrines and an outdoor altar. The geyser was the destination for pilgrimages where a Cleansing Festival would take place. The [[pilgrim]]s believed these rituals would extend their life.
;The Okaning School
:The art of [[illusion|illusory magic]] was taught at the [[Okaning School]] in [[Ventrax]]. The masters of the school were called upon in times of war to cast impressive illusions. One of the most notable achievements of the sages at the school was making their entire village disappear for two weeks.
;Seven Stone Monks Temple
:A monastic order that consisted of the seven stone monks who possessed divine magics and held secrets of enchanting such unique wondrous items as ''[[Myo-Myo's gong]]'', wielded by a famed ghost hunter long before the 14{{th}} century DR.
;T'hai Salt Flats
:Originally a vast salt lake, the [[T'hai Salt Flats]] were formed when deep underground upheaval cased the water to drain away. No plants or animals lived in this wasteland. The only known inhabitant was a [[necromancer]] named [[Utwa So]]. Utwa controlled a large number of "salt-zombies" that he created from peasants and adventurers who wandered too far into his territory.
;The [[Yengso Rocks]]
:Exactly 124 naturally carved pillars stood about 70 ft high in this region. The rocks were carved by the wind and became a holy place frequented by [[Shugenja|shukenja]] and [[monk]]s. Some believed that the stones whispered truths to those who could sit long enough to hear. Another myth stated that the rocks were once a mighty army that tried to challenge the [[Celestial Heavens]] but were turned to stone by the gods.
